title: Stewart Wallace
text:
Stewart Wallace (born 1960) is an American <a href="composer">composer</a> and <a href="Hazzan">cantor</a>.
Wallace was born in <a href="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>.
He has spent much of his career composing experimental <a href="opera">opera</a>s, from the dance-centered "Kabbalah" (1989) to the surrealist "Hopper's Wife" (1992). Two of his operas have been premiered at the <a href="Houston%20Grand%20Opera">Houston Grand Opera</a>, "<a href="Where%27s%20Dick%3F">Where's Dick?</a>" (1989) and "<a href="Harvey%20Milk%20%28opera%29">Harvey Milk</a>" (1995); the latter of which was based on the life of its <a href="Harvey%20Milk">namesake</a>. His most recent opera, "<a href="The%20Bonesetter%27s%20Daughter%20%28opera%29">The Bonesetter's Daughter</a>", uses a <a href="libretto">libretto</a> by
<a href="Amy%20Tan">Amy Tan</a> which is based on her <a href="novel">novel</a> of the <a href="The%20Bonesetter%27s%20Daughter">same name</a>. "The Bonesetter's Daughter" premiered at the <a href="War%20Memorial%20Opera%20House">War Memorial Opera House</a> of the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Opera">San Francisco Opera</a> in 2008.
The <a href="New%20York%20City%20Opera">New York City Opera</a> announced that it would stage the East Coast premiere of Wallace's “Hopper’s Wife” — a 1997 <a href="chamber%20opera">chamber opera</a> about an imagined marriage between the painter <a href="Edward%20Hopper">Edward Hopper</a> and the <a href="gossip%20columnist">gossip columnist</a> <a href="Hedda%20Hopper">Hedda Hopper</a>—at Harlem Stage from April 28 through May 1, 2016.
